message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The key to answering this question is recognizing that the patients are all presenting with post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN), a type of kidney disease that occurs after infection with certain strains of Group A Streptococcus bacteria. The disease is most common in children and usually resolves on its own within a few weeks without treatment. Therefore, the best prognosis is seen in the 8-year-old boy who undergoes no treatment. The other patients may have factors that negatively impact their prognosis, such as age or underlying medical conditions.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the disease characterizes post-infectious glomerulonephritis, which usually resolves without treatment in children. The other options have factors such as age and underlying conditions that may increase the risk of complications and worse prognosis.

The best prognosis is for the patient who undergoes no treatment, as this condition is self-limiting and typically resolves within a few weeks. The other patients may require medical intervention or have comorbidities that impact their prognosis.

The described disease is likely acute poststreptococcal glomerulonephritis (APSGN), which most commonly affects children and has a good prognosis with supportive care. The age and medical history of the other patients do not necessarily indicate a better prognosis.

Therefore, the 8-year-old boy who undergoes no treatment is likely to have the best prognosis. The other patients may have different risk factors for complications or slower recoveries.
